Diversity Indices

Source: R/diversity.evaluate.core.R
diversity.evaluate.core.Rd

Compute the following diversity indices to compare the phenotypic diversity for qualitative traits between entire collection (EC) and core set (CS).

  • Simpson's Index (\(D\)) (Simpson 1949)

  • Nei's Diversity Index or Nei's Variation Index or Simpson's Index of Diversity or Gini's Diversity Index or Gini-Simpson Index (\(H\)) (Gini 1912, 1912; Nei 1973)

  • Maximum Nei's Diversity/Variation Index or Maximum Simpson's Index of Diversity (\(H_{max}\)) (Hennink and Zeven 1990)

  • Simpson's Reciprocal Index (\(D_{R}\)) (Hennink and Zeven 1990)

  • Relative Nei's Diversity/Variation Index or Relative Simpson's Index of Diversity (\(H'\)) (Hennink and Zeven 1990)

  • Shannon or Shannon-Weaver or Shannon-Weiner Diversity Index (\(I\)) (Shannon and Weaver 1949)

  • Maximum Shannon-Weaver Diversity Index (\(I_{max}\)) (Hennink and Zeven 1990)

  • Relative Shannon-Weaver Diversity Index or Shannon Equitability Index (\(I'\)) (Hennink and Zeven 1990)

  • McIntosh Diversity Index (\(D_{Mc}\)) (McIntosh 1967)

diversity.evaluate.core(data, names, qualitative, selected)

Arguments

data

The data as a data frame object. The data frame should possess one row per individual and columns with the individual names and multiple trait/character data.

names

Name of column with the individual names as a character string

qualitative

Name of columns with the qualitative traits as a character vector.

selected

Character vector with the names of individuals selected in core collection and present in the names column.

Value

A data frame with the following columns.

Trait

The qualitative trait.

EC_No.Classes

The number of classes in the trait for EC.

EC_D

The Simpson's Index (\(D\)) for EC.

EC_H

Nei's Diversity Index (\(H\)) for EC.

EC_H.max

Maximum Nei's Diversity Index (\(H_{max}\)) for EC.

EC_D.inv

Simpson's Reciprocal Index (\(D_{R}\)) for EC.

EC_H.rel

Relative Nei's Diversity Index (\(H'\)) for EC.

EC_I

Shannon-Weaver Diversity Index (\(I\)) for EC.

EC_I.max

Maximum Shannon-Weaver Diversity Index (\(I_{max}\)) for EC.

EC_I.rel

Relative Shannon-Weaver Diversity Index (\(I'\)) for EC.

EC_D.Mc

McIntosh Diversity Index (\(D_{Mc}\)) for EC.

CS_No.Classes

The number of classes in the trait for CS.

CS_D

The Simpson's Index (\(D\)) for CS.

CS_H

Nei's Diversity Index (\(H\)) for CS.

CS_H.max

Maximum Nei's Diversity Index (\(H_{max}\)) for CS.

CS_D.inv

Simpson's Reciprocal Index (\(D_{R}\)) for CS.

CS_H.rel

Relative Nei's Diversity Index (\(H'\)) for CS.

CS_I

Shannon-Weaver Diversity Index (\(I\)) for CS.

CS_I.max

Maximum Shannon-Weaver Diversity Index (\(I_{max}\)) for CS.

CS_I.rel

Relative Shannon-Weaver Diversity Index (\(I'\)) for CS.

CS_D.Mc

McIntosh Diversity Index (\(D_{Mc}\)) for CS.

.

Details

Simpson's index (\(D\)) which estimates the probability that two accessions randomly selected will belong to the same phenotypic class of a trait, is computed as follows (Simpson 1949) .

\[D = \sum_{i = 1}^{k}p_{i}^{2}\]

Where, \(p_{i}\) denotes the proportion/fraction/frequency of accessions in the \(i\)th phenotypic class for a trait and \(k\) is the number of phenotypic classes for the trait.

The value of \(D\) can range from 0 to 1 with 0 representing maximum diversity and 1, no diversity.

\(D\) is subtracted from 1 to give Nei's diversity index or Nei's variation index or Simpson's index of diversity or Gini's diversity index or Gini-Simpson index \(H\). Greater the value of \(H\), greater the diversity (Gini 1912, 1912; Nei 1973) with a range from 0 to 1.

\[H = 1 - D\]

The maximum value of \(H\), \(H_{max}\) occurs when accessions are uniformly distributed across the phenotypic classes and is computed as follows (Hennink and Zeven 1990) .

\[H_{max} = 1 - \frac{1}{k}\]

Reciprocal of \(D\) gives the Simpson's reciprocal index (\(D_{R}\)) (Hennink and Zeven 1990) and can range from 1 to \(k\).

\[D_{R} = \frac{1}{D}\]

Relative Nei's diversity/variation index or Relative Simpson's index of diversity (\(H'\)) (Hennink and Zeven 1990) is defined as follows.

\[H' = \frac{H}{H_{max}}\]

An index of information \(I\), was described by Shannon and Weaver (1949) as follows.

\[I = -\sum_{i=1}^{k}p_{i} \log_{2}(p_{i})\]

\(I\) is described as Shannon or Shannon-Weaver or Shannon-Weiner diversity index in literature.

Alternatively, \(I\) is also computed using natural logarithm instead of logarithm to base 2.

\[I = -\sum_{i=1}^{k}p_{i} \ln(p_{i})\]

The maximum value of \(I\) (\(I_{max}\)) is \(\ln(k)\). This value occurs when each phenotypic class for a trait has the same proportion of accessions.

\[I_{max} = \log_{2}(k)\] OR \[I_{max} = \ln(k)\]

The relative Shannon-Weaver diversity index or Shannon equitability index (\(I'\)) is the Shannon diversity index (\(I\)) divided by the maximum diversity (\(I_{max}\)).

\[I' = \frac{I}{I_{max}}\]

A similar index of diversity was described by McIntosh (1967) as follows (\(D_{Mc}\)).

\[D_{Mc} = \frac{N - \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{k}n_{i}^2}}{N - \sqrt{N}}\]

Where, \(n_{i}\) denotes the number of accessions in the \(i\)th phenotypic class for a trait and \(N\) is the total number of accessions so that \(p_{i} = {n_{i}}/{N}\).

References

Gini C (1912). Variabilita e Mutabilita. Contributo allo Studio delle Distribuzioni e delle Relazioni Statistiche. [Fasc. I.]. Tipogr. di P. Cuppini, Bologna.

Gini C (1912). “Variabilita e mutabilita.” In Pizetti E, Salvemini T (eds.), Memorie di Metodologica Statistica. Liberia Eredi Virgilio Veschi, Roma, Italy.

Hennink S, Zeven AC (1990). “The interpretation of Nei and Shannon-Weaver within population variation indices.” Euphytica, 51(3), 235--240.

McIntosh RP (1967). “An index of diversity and the relation of certain concepts to diversity.” Ecology, 48(3), 392--404.

Nei M (1973). “Analysis of gene diversity in subdivided populations.” Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 70(12), 3321--3323.

Shannon CE, Weaver W (1949). The Mathematical Theory of Communication, number v. 2 in The Mathematical Theory of Communication. University of Illinois Press.

Simpson EH (1949). “Measurement of diversity.” Nature, 163(4148), 688--688.

See also

shannon, diversity

Examples


data("cassava_CC")
data("cassava_EC")

ec <- cbind(genotypes = rownames(cassava_EC), cassava_EC)
ec$genotypes <- as.character(ec$genotypes)
rownames(ec) <- NULL

core <- rownames(cassava_CC)

quant <- c("NMSR", "TTRN", "TFWSR", "TTRW", "TFWSS", "TTSW", "TTPW", "AVPW",
           "ARSR", "SRDM")
qual <- c("CUAL", "LNGS", "PTLC", "DSTA", "LFRT", "LBTEF", "CBTR", "NMLB",
          "ANGB", "CUAL9M", "LVC9M", "TNPR9M", "PL9M", "STRP", "STRC",
          "PSTR")

ec[, qual] <- lapply(ec[, qual],
                     function(x) factor(as.factor(x)))

diversity.evaluate.core(data = ec, names = "genotypes",
                        qualitative = qual, selected = core)
